text: Trading Hours and Retail Investment Performance Ed deHaan † edehaan@stanford.edu Graduate School of Business Stanford University Andrew Glover glov@uw.edu Foster School of Business University of Washington August 18, 2023 Abstract We examine the effects of stock market access, and in particular trading hours, on retail investment performance. Using discontinuities around time zone borders, we find that plausibly exogenous decreases in waking trading hours are associated with meaningful increases in retail investors’ capital gains, as reported on tax returns for the U.S. population. Our results indicate that limiting trading hours mitigates retail investors’ tendencies to trade “too much,” leading to improvements in portfolio performance. Our findings inform discussions among academics, practitioners, and regulators about the potential detrimental effects of decreasing barriers to entry for retail investors in trading markets. You invest on your time.” ~ Robinhood Markets, Inc. (2023) I. INTRODUCTION Retail investor access to capital markets has increased dramatically in recent years. For example, trading apps, fractional shares, and commission-free trades make it easier for retail investors to trade securities, and platforms such as Robinhood are beginning to offer 24-hour trading. Accordingly, trading volume from retail investors as a percentage of all trades has more than doubled in the last decade (BNY Mellon 2021). While a common public opinion seems to be that the “democratization” of capital markets is advantageous for retail investors, academic research finds that retail investors tend to trade “too much” and to their financial detriment.1 This study investigates whether easier market access in the form of expanded trading hours improves or hurts retail investors’ investment performance. A challenge in investigating our research question is identifying variation in retail investor trading hours. We use a geographic discontinuity design to exploit plausibly exogenous variation in waking trading hours for retail investors living on either side of U.S. time zone borders. Well-established evidence demonstrates that humans’ schedules are determined by social time (i.e., the local time on one’s watch) more than a universal time (i.e., the time in a specific location, such as New York City). Discrete changes in social time across time zones cause people on either side of a time zone border to exhibit discontinuous changes in behaviors, despite sharing similar demographic and environmental characteristics. Because major U.S. stock exchanges are open from 9:30AM to 4:00PM Eastern time, individuals in each time zone moving west have one hour less of the trading day that falls within their “normal waking hours,” as compared to their east-side peers (see Figure 1). Time zone borders therefore provide measurable variation in the relative ease of active morning trading for otherwise similar retail investors, and serve as our proxy for variation in trading hours.2 The effects of variation in trading hours on retail investment performance are ex ante unclear. Within our empirical context, retail investors who miss morning trading miss the hour of the day with the highest volatility, information asymmetry, and adverse selection (e.g., Gerety & Mulherin 1992; McInish & Wood 1992), and miss the opportunity to trade on the morning’s news before prices adjust.3 For example, roughly one third of earnings announcements (EAs) happen between 6:00AM and 8:30AM Eastern time, and most of the price response to EAs happens within the first few minutes of regular trading (deHaan et al. 2015; Wertz 2020). Classic rational theory indicates that trading frictions impair investment efficiency, in which case westerly retail investors likely underperform their easterly peers. However, it is also plausible that missing morning trading mitigates retail investors’ tendencies to make excessive and under- informed trades, in which case westerly investors’ average performance likely improves. text: Initial analyses include the full U.S. sample and regress Gains on a time zone count variable and year and income bracket fixed effects. We find that a one-hour decrease in waking trading hours is associated with a 3.9 percentage point increase in investment performance. However, this design tenuously assumes that traders living across the U.S. are similar across factors that determine investment performance. Our primary analyses focus on the 208 counties (13,380 observations) that are immediately adjacent to an interior time zone border. Our identifying assumption is that other than their time zones, retail investors living just to the east and west of a border are similar in ways that determine investment performance. We support this assumption by examining a wide variety of economic, demographic, education, housing, and health data, and find that border county populations are observationally identical. Moreover, counties on either side of a border have statistically similar longitudes and latitudes, meaning they have similar solar time (i.e., time relative to the sun) and environmental conditions. We regress Gains on a west-side indicator variable and use border fixed effects to contrast investors on either side of each border, in addition to year and bracket fixed effects. Retail investors just to the west of a border have 2.9 percentage points higher capital gains per year, which is consistent with barriers to market access improving investment performance. We run two sets of falsification tests to ensure that our results are not a statistical artifact or driven by general differences between east-west adjacent counties. Our first set of falsification tests is based on contiguous pseudo-borders that mimic true time zone borders but do not include true time zone borders (see Figure 4A). Reperforming the border test for 9,999 random combinations of pseudo-borders finds that only 33 trials produce a larger coefficient than our true coefficient estimate, for a Fisher p-value of 0.003. text: Our study has important implications for regulators, brokers, and exchanges that are considering expanding retail trading hours.8 For example, the SEC recently considered a proposal for 24-hour exchanges (SEC 2022; Osipovich 2021), and Robinhood recently announced 24-hour trading in select ETFs and stocks (Osipovich & Miao 2023). Our findings indicate that expanding out-of-hours retail access will likely have a material negative effect on the average retail investor’s performance, which raises serious questions about the welfare implications of such policies. Our findings also raise concerns about retail investors’ current abilities to trade 24-hours a day in assets such as cryptocurrencies and NFTs. Our study’s primary academic contribution is to the accounting literature on retail investment. As reviewed by Blankespoor et al. (2020), many studies since Cready (1988) and Lee (1992) find that retail investors under-perform by trading in ways that are systematically less-timely and less-informed than professional investors. Another line of studies investigates the effects of regulations on retail investor welfare, including regulations relating to market participation and design (e.g., Christensen et al., 2019; Gerakos et al. 2013; Zingales 2009).9 Our study lies at the intersection of these literatures. Rather than examining the specific disclosures or biases that drive ill-informed retail trades, we model the collective effects of ill-informed retail trading on portfolio performance to investigate the types of regulations that are likely to enhance investors’ financial wellbeing. In doing so, we respond to Blankespoor et al.’s (2020, p21) call for accounting research on whether and how regulators can deter active retail trading in favor of longer-term, passive investment strategies. THEORY AND BACKGROUND LITERATURE There are two steps in our hypothesized causal chain: 1) that time zones affect retail trading hours, and 2) that retail trading hours affect investment performance. We discuss each in the following subsections. 2.1. Time Zones and Retail Trading Chronobiology research shows that social time largely dictates individuals’ daily activities, even when social time conflicts with their natural schedule preferences (Roenneberg et. al 2003; Witmann et al. 2006; Roenneberg et al. 2019; Korman et al. 2020; Aschoff et al. 1971; Hamermesh et al. 2008). In other words, the average east- and west-coaster wake up, eat breakfast, and go to work at roughly the same local time. Trading hours at traditional U.S. exchanges follow Eastern time, with regular hours from 9:30AM to 4:00PM. These are productive waking hours for retail investors on the East coast but fall increasingly outside of productive waking hours for investors in more westerly time zones. Individuals in the Pacific time zone can actively trade from 6:30AM to 1:00PM local time. Sample Selection IRS SOI publishes annual data on aggregated taxpayer 1040 filings by county and income bracket.15 Form 1040, and its sub-types, is the required tax filing for nearly all individuals with income exceeding the standard deduction and anyone below that threshold claiming a refund. The SOI data are published a few years after each tax year. The 1040 data used in our study are available from 2010 through 2019. Within each county, 1040 fields are aggregated based on taxpayers’ adjusted gross income (AGI) bracket. Six AGI brackets span negative income to $199,999, and a seventh bracket includes $200,000 and more.16 1040 fields are summed for all individuals within the county-bracket and rounded to the nearest 10. To preserve anonymity, SOI combines fields representing fewer than 20 returns into the next closest income bracket. SOI also reports the count of returns with non-zero values for each 1040 field.
